title: Semantic Search for the Enterprise

We do semantic linking.
We also do search driven applications.
So this talk is about semantic search for the enterprise.
So what is the semantic web?

It was proposed by Tim Berners Lee, the founder of the World Wide Web, and the idea is that computers should be able to evaluate information according to its meaning to connect information to reason with it, to inferences, even generate new information, and.

My vision for Enterprise search is that our enterprise search will become they central information system for all enterprise data.
So you not only have data from your content management system, but you have all kinds of data.
You have data from your PC system from your subsystem and all this goes into this one single search engine or enterprise search engine and you will be able to answer questions like.
What is the phone number of?
This this guy in which Department does he work?
Who is an ex?
Give me experts in this in that technology?
Who's the director of this project give me all invoices of this customer of this supplier?
So give me all my materials needed to produce stuff like that.
These kinds of questions.
And I think in order to realize such a system, we need more than just a fulltext index, even for storing.
The information that we can extract from the documents.
I think we have to combine a fulltext index with an RDF RDF store so RDF stores have originally been designed as a metered data model for machine readable information.

They store triples subject, predicate, object travels and they are general model for knowledge representation, and I think we should use them to store the structured data from the enterprise, either the structured data from.

Maybe your P systems from from other databases but also the structured data that we found find in documents by by using information extraction technology and what we also need is to link the documents and the structured data.
But these RDF stores are missing is and they have been designed as a storage for machine usability, not for human usability.

Yeah, I think that that's true, but.
The the problem then is to to link the the information to link documents to two entities or two projects or whatever.
Yeah, and that's part of the task.
And then of course you're going to link the data in a text document back to original data source, so the complexity of repository management when there are no links, it's big.

Yeah, and in fact to to take the defense of Francois's position and he excuses himself, but he has a back problem nagging back problems, so he had to return back home when Francois says, quote unquote enterprise search market is dead is only saying that just?

Looking at Enterprise search as a box isolated from the rest of the Corporation activity, that is that but plugging enterprise search, plugging search technology into the overall enterprise activity, having the search window embedded into the application so that you don't have to leave the application to do the search and vice versa.
Once you do the search, being able to trigger the application an execute something on the data that you have found.
All of that is still very active, and in fact this is what exactly it is doing today there are.
